title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act includes sections on short title, definitions, privacy protection for customer information, enforcement, civil liability, criminal penalty, relation to State laws, and agency guidance. The Act defines terms like "customer" and "customer information of a financial institution." The Financial Information Privacy Act defines terms like "customer information of a financial institution" as any information maintained by a financial institution derived from the relationship with a customer. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines "document" as any information in any form and "financial institution" as any institution providing financial services to customers with credit, deposit, trust, or other financial accounts. This includes depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines "financial institution" broadly to include depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define this term through regulations. The Act prohibits obtaining customer information by false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution by false pretenses, such as making false statements to deceive employees into releasing the information. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through fraudulent means, including making false statements to deceive employees into releasing the information. This can involve providing forged, counterfeit, or stolen documents to deceive the institution. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through fraudulent means, including providing forged, counterfeit, or stolen documents to deceive employees into releasing the information. It is also a violation to solicit someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through fraudulent means. "Limitation on state action during federal proceedings - If the FTC or any relevant agency initiates a civil action for a violation of this title, no State can bring a separate action against the same defendant for the same violation. Civil liability for non-compliance with this title applies to individuals, excluding financial institutions, regarding customer information." "Any person failing to comply with this title regarding financial institutions or customer information is liable for actual damages sustained by the institution or customer, plus any benefits received from the non-compliance." The criminal penalty for violating section 1003 includes fines according to title 18, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases. Attorneys' fees are awarded in successful enforcement actions. Sec. 1006 outlines the criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving illegal activities exceeding $100,000 in a 12-month period. Sec. 1007 states that this title does not override state laws unless they are inconsistent with it, and in such cases, only to the extent of the inconsistency. State laws providing greater protection than this title are not considered inconsistent. Sec. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to prevent prohibited activities. Before the end of 18 months from enactment, a report must be submitted to Congress by the Comptroller General in consultation with relevant agencies. Before the end of the 18-month period from enactment, the Comptroller General, in consultation with relevant agencies, must submit a report to Congress on the efficacy of remedies for obtaining financial information by fraudulent means and recommendations for legislative or regulatory action to address threats to financial privacy.
